        Focus on dichotomous outcomes from ALL data sources: main text, figures, tables,
        and supplementary materials. Include zero-event outcomes (0/N patients).

[[ ## markdown_content ## ]] # *Double-Blind Comparison of Meclofenama te Sodium Plus Codeine, Meclofenama te Sodium, Codeine, and Placebo for Relief of Pain Following Surgical Removal of Third Molars* # JAMES A. GIGLIO, DDS, MED,\* AND DANIEL M. LASKIN, DDS, MSt A single-dose, randomized, double-blind, parallel-treatment study was performed in 200 outpatients with acute pain caused by the surgical removal of impacted third molars. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, meclofenamate 100 mg, codeine 60 mg, and placebo treatment groups were compared for sum of pain intensity differences, peak pain intensity difference, sum of pain relief scores, peak pain relief, number of observations at which pain was half relieved, overall evaluation of effectiveness, and time to remedication with a backup analgesic. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg was significantly more effective (P < .005) than codeine 60 mg for all variables except number of observations at which pain was half relieved. Both meclofenamate-codeine combinations and meclofenamate 100 mg alone were significantly more effective (P < .005) than placebo for all variables. Eleven adverse experiences were reported in 7 patients (3.5%); the most common was somnolence in 1 patient receiving meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, in 2 treated with meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and in 1 treated with codeine 60 mg. Meclofenamate sodium (Meclomen, Parke-Davis Pharmaceutical Research Division, Warner-Lambert Co, Morris Plains, NJ), a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, inhibits prostaglandin synthesis and competes with formed prostaglandins for receptor sites. L-4 It has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for treatment of signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. Published literature provides evidence that meclofenamate is safe and effective in the treatment of patients with acute dental pain following third molar extraction,5q6 rheumatoid arthritis,'\*\* osteoarthritis,9-" ankylosing spondylitis,'2\*13 and gout,14 and for the pain of episiotomy.15\*'6 The objectives of this study were to assess the efficacy and safety of a fixed combination of meclofenamate, which acts peripherally, and codeine, which acts centrally, and to evaluate whether such a combination is more beneficial than either ingredient acting alone in patients with pain due to oral surgery. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg was compared with its components, with placebo, and with meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg.17 Received from the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medical College of Virginia, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond. \* Associate Professor. t Professor and Chairman. Presented at the American Association for Dental Research, San Francisco, CA, March 1989. Address correspondence and reprint requests to Dr Laskin: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medical College of Virginia, PO Box 566, MCV Station, Richmond, VA 23298- 0566. **0 1990 American Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons** **0278-2391/90/4808-0003\$3.00/O** # Materials and Methods # **STUDY DESIGN** This was a single-dose, randomized, doubleblind, placebo-controlled, parallel-treatment study in outpatients with moderate or severe pain **caused** by the surgical removal of impacted third molars. Before the study, the protocol was approved by the Committee on the Conduct of Human Research of Virginia Commonwealth University. Each patient was supplied with a diary to record information on efficacy and safety over 6 hours following study drug administration and instructed to return it at the next scheduled visit to the study site. #### **PATIENT SELECTION** Selected for the study were outpatients at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery of the Medical College of Virginia, 16 to 37 years old, who were scheduled to undergo the surgical removal of impacted third molars, at least one of which was a partial or full bony impaction. Before participation, each patient signed a written informed consent statement, medical histories were taken, and physical examinations were performed. Patients were excluded from the study if they had medical conditions that contraindicated the use of any of the study medications or if they had known hypersensitivities, allergies, or idiosyncratic reactions to any of the study medications. Female patients were excluded if they were pregnant or nursing. In addition, no patient could be taking any medication that would confound the effects of the study drug or have taken any analgesics or anti-inflammatory agents within a 4-hour period before surgery. #### **ANESTHETIC REGIMEN** Patients were treated under local block (mandibular teeth) or infiltration (maxillary teeth) anesthesia using 2% lidocaine with epinephrine l:lOO,OOO supplemented with intravenous diazepam and N20/02 administered by nasal mask. If necessary, methohexital was given intravenously. # **STUDY MEDICATION** All study medications were identical in appearance. Each patient received a single dose consisting of one of the following: 1) one capsule of meclofenamate 100 mg and one of codeine 60 mg, 2) one capsule of meclofenamate 50 mg and one of codeine 30 mg, 3) one capsule of meclofenamate 100 mg and one of placebo, 4) one capsule of codeine 60 mg and one of placebo, or 5) two capsules of placebo. Backup medication of acetaminophen 300 mg plus codeine 30 mg, one or two every 6 hours, was provided to patients for use if additional relief from postsurgical pain was needed. # **STUDYEVALUATION** The efficacy evaluation was based on patient diary records. At 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 hours after taking the study drug, patients rated pain relief and pain intensity. Pain intensity was scored as none = 0, slight = 1, moderate = 2, or severe = 3. Pain relief was scored as none = 0, a little = 1, some = 2, a lot = 3, or complete = 4. Patients also indicated whether the pain was at least half relieved at each of the observation points (yes or no) and gave the time of administration of the backup medication. At the end of the 6-hour study period, each patient evaluated the study drug as excellent = I, very good = 2, good = 3, fair = 4, or poor = 5. A pain intensity difference (PID) score was calculated for each of the seven posttreatment observation times for each patient by subtracting the posttreatment pain intensity score from the one at baseline (a greater positive score indicates greater improvement). A sum of pain intensity differences (SPID) was then determined by adding the seven PID ratings; a sum of pain relief scores (TOTPAR) was determined in the analogous manner by adding a patient's seven pain relief scores. The variables of interest for efficacy were adjusted mean values for SPID and peak PID; TOT-PAR, peak pain relief, number of observations at which pain was half relieved; overall evaluation of study medication effectiveness; and time to remedication with a backup analgesic. The safety evaluation was based on the incidence and severity of adverse experiences that occurred during the 6-hour study period and were recorded in the patient diaries. # **STATISTICAL METHODOLOGY** As treatment groups were significantly different (x2 = 10.46, *P =* .033) with respect to baseline pain intensity, the statistical methodology for the effrcacy data used an ANCOVA with baseline pain intensity as covariate to adjust for this difference. (Although all patients had moderate or severe baseline pain intensity, there were significantly more patients with severe pain in the groups receiving meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg or meclofenamate 100 mg.) Pairwise f-test comparisons were performed on adjusted means. These adjusted mean scores are reported as least square means. Because there were 10 possible pairwise comparisons, a Bonferroni adjusted significance level of 0.005 (0.05 + 10) was used for every pairwise comparison to preserve the overall experiment-wide significance level of 0.05. Computation was performed using the SAS procedure General Linear Model. Summary tables were produced for adverse experience data. # Results # PATIENT POPULATION Two hundred patients, 35 men and 165 women, were enrolled and received study medication. There were 142 whites (71%), 51 blacks (25.5%), and 7 (3.5%) patients of other races, ranging in age from 16 to 37 years (mean, 22.7). Table 1 shows these data by treatment group, as well as the number of patients in each treatment group. There were no significant differences between study groups in mean time from end of surgery to treatment with study medication. #### EFFICACY ANALYSES # *Exclusions From Efficacy Analyses* There were no withdrawals among the 200 patients. However, 4 patients were excluded from all efficacy analyses. One patient who received meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg and 2 patients who received codeine were excluded because they took backup medication less than 1 hour after study medication. Another placebo-treated patient was excluded because she took the study medication intended for another patient 30 minutes after she took her own. One additional patient who received meclofenamate 50 mg and codeine 30 mg was excluded from the analyses for TOTPAR and # Table 1. Patient Characteristics peak pain value because she had two values for pain relief missing in the first 4 hours following study medication. # *Pain Intensity* Adjusted PID scores over 6 hours for each of the five treatment groups are shown in Fig 1. The group that took meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg had the largest mean values (greatest improvement) at each time point, followed by groups receiving meclofenamate 100 mg and meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg. Both codeine and placebo groups showed negative adjusted mean values during most of the study, indicating an increase in pain intensity from baseline: codeine from 2 to 6 hours and placebo from 0.5 to 6 hours. The statistical analysis of adjusted mean SPID and adjusted mean peak PID (n = 196) showed that meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg reduced pain intensity significantly more than either codeine or placebo *(P < 0.005)* overall and for peak values. In addition, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate 100 mg alone were both statistically superior to placebo for both measures (Table 2). # *Pain Relief* Adjusted mean pain relief scores over 6 hours are shown in Fig 2. Meclofenamate plus codeine produced the greatest pain relief over time. The poorest pain relief over time was observed for codeine and placebo: their adjusted mean scores ranged between 0 and 1 (0 = no relief, 1 = a little relief) for codeine at 0.5 and 2 through 6 hours, and for placebo throughout the entire observation period. The statistical analysis of adjusted mean TOT-PAR and adjusted mean pain relief demonstrated results analogous to those of adjusted mean SPID | Variable | Treatment (mg) | | | | | | |----------|----------------------|------------------------|-------------------|------------------|---------------|--------------------| | | M1OO+C60

Again, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate 100 mg alone were associated with statistically greater adjusted mean values than placebo for both measures (Table 3). In addition, pain was at least half relieved at significantly more observations with both meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate alone than with placebo alone. The mean results were meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 3.46 observations; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 2.59; meclofenamate 100 mg, 2.51; codeine, 1.52; and placebo, 0.74. # *Overall Evaluation of Study Drugs* Each patient evaluated the effectiveness of the study drug (the potential range was 1, excellent, to 5, poor; n = 196). Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg had a significantly larger mean score (P < .005) than codeine or placebo. In addition, both meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate 100 mg had a significantly better rating than placebo. The mean results were as follows: meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 2.15; meclofenamate IO0 mg, 1.87; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 1.65; codeine, 1.15; and placebo, 0.51. #### *Time to Remedication* Time to remedication was the time between taking the study medication and taking the backup medication. For patients who did not take a backup medication during the 6-hour posttreatment period, ![](_page_4_Figure_1.jpeg) it was set at 6 hours. The meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and meclofenamate 100 mg treatment groups had significantly longer adjusted mean times to remedication with a backup analgesic drug (P < .005) than the placebo treatment group (n = 196). The mean times, in hours, were as follows: meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 3.98; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 3.78; meclofenamate 100 mg, 3.43; codeine 60 mg, 2.89; and placebo, 1.80. # SAFETY A total of 11 adverse events (regardless of possible relation to study drug) were reported by 7 (3.5%) of 200 patients: meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 2 (5.0%) of 40 patients; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 4 (10%) of 40 pa- | Table 3. | | | Adjusted Mean TOTPAR and Peak | |----------|-----------------------|--|-------------------------------| | | Pain Relief (n = 195) | | | | Treatment Group | Number

None was considered serious. Patients in the meclofenamate 100 mg and placebo treatment groups did not report any adverse experiences. The most common adverse experience was somnolence, which occurred in 1 (2.5%) of the patients who received meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 2 (5.0%) who received meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and 1 (2.6%) who received codeine 60 mg (Table 4). #### Discussion Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) have proven to be effective in relieving postoperative pain.18 Like all members of this class of drugs, meclofenamate acts peripherally by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis and by binding competitively at the prostaglandin receptor sites. Meclofenamate has also been found to be an in vitro inhibitor of human leukocyte 5-lipoxygenase activity. This study was undertaken to determine the feasibility and desirability of combining meclofenamate with codeine to obtain greater pain relief or control than can be achieved with either drug alone in conditions producing moderate or severe pain. Such a fixedcombination product may be clinically advantageous for patients requiring both central and peripheral analgesia. The results of this study show that meclofenamate with codeine provides greater pain relief. messages.content:
Your input fields are:
1. `study_metadata_json` (str): Study metadata as JSON string with first_author,  population_code
2. `intervention_json` (str): Single intervention details as JSON string with intervention_code, intervention_description, n_analyzed
3. `outcome_json` (str): Single outcome details as JSON string with all outcome fields including outcome_type, follow_up_time, n_events_number, etc.
Your output fields are:
1. `reasoning` (str): 
2. `structured_record_json` (str): Complete structured record as JSON string with exactly these fields:
        - First_Author (string): First author last name (e.g., "Cooper")
        - Population (integer): Population code (1-4)
        - Intervention_Code (integer): Intervention code (1-11)
        - Intervention_Description (string): Full intervention description with dose
        - Outcome_Type (integer): Outcome type (1=rescue analgesia 6h, 2=rescue analgesia 4h, 4=rescue analgesia pulpitis, 5=adverse effects, 6=other)
        - Outcome_Other_Specify (string): Detailed outcome description for type 6, or empty string for other types
        - Follow_Up_Time (string): Time point (e.g., "24hrs", "6 hours")
        - N_Analyzed (integer): Number of participants analyzed
        - Adverse_Effect_Specify (string): Specific adverse effect name for type 5, or empty string for other types
        - Adverse_Effects_All_Study (string): All study adverse effects if not reported per arm, or empty string
        - N_Events_Number (integer): Number of patients with this outcome
        - N_Events_Percentage (float): Percentage of patients with this outcome
        - Comments (string): Study-specific methodology, design notes, and extraction details
        
        FIELD MAPPING RULES:
        - For outcome_type 1,2,4 (rescue analgesia): Adverse_Effect_Specify="" and Outcome_Other_Specify=""
        - For outcome_type 5 (adverse effects): Outcome_Other_Specify="" and Adverse_Effect_Specify=specific adverse event name
        - For outcome_type 6 (other outcomes): Adverse_Effect_Specify="" and Outcome_Other_Specify=detailed outcome description
        - Always include extraction methodology and data source information in Comments
        - Ensure mathematical validation: (N_Events_Number/N_Analyzed)*100 = N_Events_Percentage
        - Use appropriate analysis populations (efficacy vs safety) based on outcome type
        
        Example: {"First_Author": "Cooper",  "Population": 2, "Intervention_Code": 10, "Intervention_Description": "Naproxen sodium 440mg", "Outcome_Type": 5, "Outcome_Other_Specify": "", "Follow_Up_Time": "24hrs", "N_Analyzed": 166, "Adverse_Effect_Specify": "Paraesthesia oral", "Adverse_Effects_All_Study": "", "N_Events_Number": 1, "N_Events_Percentage": 0.6, "Comments": "extracted from supplementary table 3, safety population, single dose study"}
All interactions will be structured in the following way, with the appropriate values filled in.

[[ ## study_metadata_json ## ]]
{study_metadata_json}

[[ ## intervention_json ## ]]
{intervention_json}

[[ ## outcome_json ## ]]
{outcome_json}

[[ ## reasoning ## ]]
{reasoning}

[[ ## structured_record_json ## ]]
{structured_record_json}

[[ ## completed ## ]]
In adhering to this structure, your objective is: 
        Structure extracted data into the final comprehensive dichotomous outcome format.
        
        This combines study metadata, intervention details, and any outcome data (rescue analgesia,
        adverse events, or other outcomes) into the standardized format used for systematic review
        and meta-analysis. Each record represents one outcome for one intervention in one study.

messages.content:
Your input fields are:
1. `markdown_content` (str): Full markdown content of the medical research paper including supplementary materials
2. `intervention_description` (str): Specific intervention to extract outcomes for (e.g., 'Ibuprofen 400mg', 'Placebo')
Your output fields are:
1. `reasoning` (str): 
2. `all_outcomes_json` (str): JSON string containing list of ALL outcomes for the specified intervention. Each outcome object must have:
        
        MANDATORY FIELDS FOR ALL OUTCOMES:
        - outcome_type (integer): Outcome type code where:
          1=Rescue analgesia at 6 hours
          2=Rescue analgesia at 4 hours  
          4=Rescue analgesia for pulpitis population
          5=Adverse effects (nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, dizziness, headache, etc.)
          6=Other outcomes (pain relief, time to onset, etc.)
        - follow_up_time (string): Exact time point when outcome was measured (e.g., "6 hours", "24hrs", "4 hours", "7 days")
        - n_analyzed (integer): Number of participants analyzed for this specific outcome
        - n_events_number (integer): Number of patients who experienced this outcome
        - n_events_percentage (float): Percentage of patients who experienced this outcome (e.g., 17.5, 0.6, 2.4, 0.0)
        
        CONDITIONAL FIELDS:
        - adverse_effect_specify (string): Specific adverse effect name if outcome_type=5 (e.g., "Drowsiness (sleepy, tired)", "Paraesthesia oral", "Vomiting"). Use "NA" if outcome_type5
        - other_outcome_specify (string): Detailed description if outcome_type=6 (e.g., "Time to meaningful pain relief", "Pain intensity difference"). Use "NA" if outcome_type6
        - adverse_effects_all_study (string): List of all adverse effects if not reported per study arm, or "NA" if reported per arm
        
        DOCUMENTATION FIELDS:
        - extraction_notes (string): Technical documentation including data source ("From Table 2", "From Figure 5", "From Supplementary Table 3"), extraction method ("Direct from table", "Interpreted from Kaplan-Meier curve"), and population used ("Per-protocol population", "Safety population", "ITT population")
        - comments (string): Study-specific information including single vs multiple dose design, surgical techniques mentioned, methodological features, dropout rates, calculation details
        
        EXTRACTION REQUIREMENTS:
        - Extract EVERY outcome reported, including zero-event outcomes (0/N)
        - Create separate entries for each time point assessment
        - Include outcomes from ALL data sources (main text, figures, supplements)
        - Use appropriate analysis populations (efficacy vs safety)
        - Document any calculations or interpretations performed
        
        Example: [
          {"outcome_type": 1, "follow_up_time": "6 hours", "n_analyzed": 40, "n_events_number": 15, "n_events_percentage": 37.5, "adverse_effect_specify": "NA", "other_outcome_specify": "NA", "adverse_effects_all_study": "NA", "extraction_notes": "From Table 3, per-protocol population", "comments": "single dose study with overnight monitoring"},
          {"outcome_type": 5, "follow_up_time": "24 hours", "n_analyzed": 40, "n_events_number": 7, "n_events_percentage": 17.5, "adverse_effect_specify": "Drowsiness (sleepy, tired)", "other_outcome_specify": "NA", "adverse_effects_all_study": "NA", "extraction_notes": "From safety table, safety population", "comments": "mild to moderate severity"}
        ]
All interactions will be structured in the following way, with the appropriate values filled in.

[[ ## markdown_content ## ]]
{markdown_content}

[[ ## intervention_description ## ]]
{intervention_description}

[[ ## reasoning ## ]]
{reasoning}

[[ ## all_outcomes_json ## ]]
{all_outcomes_json}

[[ ## completed ## ]]
In adhering to this structure, your objective is: 
        Extract ALL outcomes from medical research paper for systematic review.
        
        This implements COMPLETE DATA CAPTURE methodology - extract every data point
        including rescue analgesia, adverse events, and other outcomes at all time points.
        Focus on dichotomous outcomes from ALL data sources: main text, figures, tables,
        and supplementary materials. Include zero-event outcomes (0/N patients).

[[ ## markdown_content ## ]] # *Double-Blind Comparison of Meclofenama te Sodium Plus Codeine, Meclofenama te Sodium, Codeine, and Placebo for Relief of Pain Following Surgical Removal of Third Molars* # JAMES A. GIGLIO, DDS, MED,\* AND DANIEL M. LASKIN, DDS, MSt A single-dose, randomized, double-blind, parallel-treatment study was performed in 200 outpatients with acute pain caused by the surgical removal of impacted third molars. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, meclofenamate 100 mg, codeine 60 mg, and placebo treatment groups were compared for sum of pain intensity differences, peak pain intensity difference, sum of pain relief scores, peak pain relief, number of observations at which pain was half relieved, overall evaluation of effectiveness, and time to remedication with a backup analgesic. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg was significantly more effective (P < .005) than codeine 60 mg for all variables except number of observations at which pain was half relieved. Both meclofenamate-codeine combinations and meclofenamate 100 mg alone were significantly more effective (P < .005) than placebo for all variables. Eleven adverse experiences were reported in 7 patients (3.5%); the most common was somnolence in 1 patient receiving meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, in 2 treated with meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and in 1 treated with codeine 60 mg. Meclofenamate sodium (Meclomen, Parke-Davis Pharmaceutical Research Division, Warner-Lambert Co, Morris Plains, NJ), a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, inhibits prostaglandin synthesis and competes with formed prostaglandins for receptor sites. L-4 It has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for treatment of signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. Published literature provides evidence that meclofenamate is safe and effective in the treatment of patients with acute dental pain following third molar extraction,5q6 rheumatoid arthritis,'\*\* osteoarthritis,9-" ankylosing spondylitis,'2\*13 and gout,14 and for the pain of episiotomy.15\*'6 The objectives of this study were to assess the efficacy and safety of a fixed combination of meclofenamate, which acts peripherally, and codeine, which acts centrally, and to evaluate whether such a combination is more beneficial than either ingredient acting alone in patients with pain due to oral surgery. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg was compared with its components, with placebo, and with meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg.17 Received from the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medical College of Virginia, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond. \* Associate Professor. t Professor and Chairman. Presented at the American Association for Dental Research, San Francisco, CA, March 1989. Address correspondence and reprint requests to Dr Laskin: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medical College of Virginia, PO Box 566, MCV Station, Richmond, VA 23298- 0566. **0 1990 American Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons** **0278-2391/90/4808-0003\$3.00/O** # Materials and Methods # **STUDY DESIGN** This was a single-dose, randomized, doubleblind, placebo-controlled, parallel-treatment study in outpatients with moderate or severe pain **caused** by the surgical removal of impacted third molars. Before the study, the protocol was approved by the Committee on the Conduct of Human Research of Virginia Commonwealth University. Each patient was supplied with a diary to record information on efficacy and safety over 6 hours following study drug administration and instructed to return it at the next scheduled visit to the study site. #### **PATIENT SELECTION** Selected for the study were outpatients at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery of the Medical College of Virginia, 16 to 37 years old, who were scheduled to undergo the surgical removal of impacted third molars, at least one of which was a partial or full bony impaction. Before participation, each patient signed a written informed consent statement, medical histories were taken, and physical examinations were performed. Patients were excluded from the study if they had medical conditions that contraindicated the use of any of the study medications or if they had known hypersensitivities, allergies, or idiosyncratic reactions to any of the study medications. Female patients were excluded if they were pregnant or nursing. In addition, no patient could be taking any medication that would confound the effects of the study drug or have taken any analgesics or anti-inflammatory agents within a 4-hour period before surgery. #### **ANESTHETIC REGIMEN** Patients were treated under local block (mandibular teeth) or infiltration (maxillary teeth) anesthesia using 2% lidocaine with epinephrine l:lOO,OOO supplemented with intravenous diazepam and N20/02 administered by nasal mask. If necessary, methohexital was given intravenously. # **STUDY MEDICATION** All study medications were identical in appearance. Each patient received a single dose consisting of one of the following: 1) one capsule of meclofenamate 100 mg and one of codeine 60 mg, 2) one capsule of meclofenamate 50 mg and one of codeine 30 mg, 3) one capsule of meclofenamate 100 mg and one of placebo, 4) one capsule of codeine 60 mg and one of placebo, or 5) two capsules of placebo. Backup medication of acetaminophen 300 mg plus codeine 30 mg, one or two every 6 hours, was provided to patients for use if additional relief from postsurgical pain was needed. # **STUDYEVALUATION** The efficacy evaluation was based on patient diary records. At 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 hours after taking the study drug, patients rated pain relief and pain intensity. Pain intensity was scored as none = 0, slight = 1, moderate = 2, or severe = 3. Pain relief was scored as none = 0, a little = 1, some = 2, a lot = 3, or complete = 4. Patients also indicated whether the pain was at least half relieved at each of the observation points (yes or no) and gave the time of administration of the backup medication. At the end of the 6-hour study period, each patient evaluated the study drug as excellent = I, very good = 2, good = 3, fair = 4, or poor = 5. A pain intensity difference (PID) score was calculated for each of the seven posttreatment observation times for each patient by subtracting the posttreatment pain intensity score from the one at baseline (a greater positive score indicates greater improvement). A sum of pain intensity differences (SPID) was then determined by adding the seven PID ratings; a sum of pain relief scores (TOTPAR) was determined in the analogous manner by adding a patient's seven pain relief scores. The variables of interest for efficacy were adjusted mean values for SPID and peak PID; TOT-PAR, peak pain relief, number of observations at which pain was half relieved; overall evaluation of study medication effectiveness; and time to remedication with a backup analgesic. The safety evaluation was based on the incidence and severity of adverse experiences that occurred during the 6-hour study period and were recorded in the patient diaries. # **STATISTICAL METHODOLOGY** As treatment groups were significantly different (x2 = 10.46, *P =* .033) with respect to baseline pain intensity, the statistical methodology for the effrcacy data used an ANCOVA with baseline pain intensity as covariate to adjust for this difference. (Although all patients had moderate or severe baseline pain intensity, there were significantly more patients with severe pain in the groups receiving meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg or meclofenamate 100 mg.) Pairwise f-test comparisons were performed on adjusted means. These adjusted mean scores are reported as least square means. Because there were 10 possible pairwise comparisons, a Bonferroni adjusted significance level of 0.005 (0.05 + 10) was used for every pairwise comparison to preserve the overall experiment-wide significance level of 0.05. Computation was performed using the SAS procedure General Linear Model. Summary tables were produced for adverse experience data. # Results # PATIENT POPULATION Two hundred patients, 35 men and 165 women, were enrolled and received study medication. There were 142 whites (71%), 51 blacks (25.5%), and 7 (3.5%) patients of other races, ranging in age from 16 to 37 years (mean, 22.7). Table 1 shows these data by treatment group, as well as the number of patients in each treatment group. There were no significant differences between study groups in mean time from end of surgery to treatment with study medication. #### EFFICACY ANALYSES # *Exclusions From Efficacy Analyses* There were no withdrawals among the 200 patients. However, 4 patients were excluded from all efficacy analyses. One patient who received meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg and 2 patients who received codeine were excluded because they took backup medication less than 1 hour after study medication. Another placebo-treated patient was excluded because she took the study medication intended for another patient 30 minutes after she took her own. One additional patient who received meclofenamate 50 mg and codeine 30 mg was excluded from the analyses for TOTPAR and # Table 1. Patient Characteristics peak pain value because she had two values for pain relief missing in the first 4 hours following study medication. # *Pain Intensity* Adjusted PID scores over 6 hours for each of the five treatment groups are shown in Fig 1. The group that took meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg had the largest mean values (greatest improvement) at each time point, followed by groups receiving meclofenamate 100 mg and meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg. Both codeine and placebo groups showed negative adjusted mean values during most of the study, indicating an increase in pain intensity from baseline: codeine from 2 to 6 hours and placebo from 0.5 to 6 hours. The statistical analysis of adjusted mean SPID and adjusted mean peak PID (n = 196) showed that meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg reduced pain intensity significantly more than either codeine or placebo *(P < 0.005)* overall and for peak values. In addition, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate 100 mg alone were both statistically superior to placebo for both measures (Table 2). # *Pain Relief* Adjusted mean pain relief scores over 6 hours are shown in Fig 2. Meclofenamate plus codeine produced the greatest pain relief over time. The poorest pain relief over time was observed for codeine and placebo: their adjusted mean scores ranged between 0 and 1 (0 = no relief, 1 = a little relief) for codeine at 0.5 and 2 through 6 hours, and for placebo throughout the entire observation period. The statistical analysis of adjusted mean TOT-PAR and adjusted mean pain relief demonstrated results analogous to those of adjusted mean SPID | Variable | Treatment (mg) | | | | | | |----------|----------------------|------------------------|-------------------|------------------|---------------|--------------------| | | M1OO+C60

In addition, pain was at least half relieved at significantly more observations with both meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate alone than with placebo alone. For patients who did not take a backup medication during the 6-hour posttreatment period, ![](_page_4_Figure_1.jpeg) it was set at 6 hours. The meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and meclofenamate 100 mg treatment groups had significantly longer adjusted mean times to remedication with a backup analgesic drug (P < .005) than the placebo treatment group (n = 196). The mean times, in hours, were as follows: meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 3.98; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 3.78; meclofenamate 100 mg, 3.43; codeine 60 mg, 2.89; and placebo, 1.80. # SAFETY A total of 11 adverse events (regardless of possible relation to study drug) were reported by 7 (3.5%) of 200 patients: meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 2 (5.0%) of 40 patients; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 4 (10%) of 40 pa- | Table 3. | | | Adjusted Mean TOTPAR and Peak | |----------|-----------------------|--|-------------------------------| | | Pain Relief (n = 195) | | | | Treatment Group | Number

None was considered serious. Patients in the meclofenamate 100 mg and placebo treatment groups did not report any adverse experiences. The most common adverse experience was somnolence, which occurred in 1 (2.5%) of the patients who received meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 2 (5.0%) who received meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and 1 (2.6%) who received codeine 60 mg (Table 4). #### Discussion Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) have proven to be effective in relieving postoperative pain.18 Like all members of this class of drugs, meclofenamate acts peripherally by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis and by binding competitively at the prostaglandin receptor sites. Meclofenamate has also been found to be an in vitro inhibitor of human leukocyte 5-lipoxygenase activity. This study was undertaken to determine the feasibility and desirability of combining meclofenamate with codeine to obtain greater pain relief or control than can be achieved with either drug alone in conditions producing moderate or severe pain. Such a fixedcombination product may be clinically advantageous for patients requiring both central and peripheral analgesia. The results of this study show that meclofenamate with codeine provides greater pain relief. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg was also significantly more effective (Z' < .005) than codeine 60 mg for all variables except for the adjusted mean number of observations at which pain was half relieved. The combination of meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg did have a better clinical efficacy response than meclofenamate alone, but not at the stringent *P < .005* significance level. Both meclofenamate combinations used in this study were well tolerated. On acute dosage, only 2 of 40 patients with the higher dosage and 4 of 40 with the lower dosage had adverse experiences. The most common symptom was somnolence. Gastrointestinal distress attributed to the combination was reported in only 2 patients. In addition to its excellent effect on postsurgical pain, meclofenamate plus codeine has a further advantage not investigated in this study. Because this combination is anti-inflammatory as well as analgesic, it provides an added beneficial effect often required in the postsurgical period. This makes the combination preferable to acetaminophen and codeine, which does not have this property. # References - 1. raw_entry.response:
ModelResponse(id='M4LMaNi6NLuNjMcP_cLsqAg', created=1758233094, model='gemini-2.5-pro', object='chat.completion', system_fingerprint=None, choices=[Choices(finish_reason='stop', index=0, message=Message(content='[[ ## reasoning ## ]]
The reasoning for the extraction is as follows:
1.  **Identify Intervention Group and Population Size**: The target intervention is "Codeine 60mg". According to Table 1, 39 patients were randomized to this group (`n=39`). This number is confirmed in Table 4 for the safety analysis. The efficacy analyses used n=37 for this group after two patients were excluded, as stated in the "Exclusions From Efficacy Analyses" section.

2.  **Scan for Dichotomous Outcomes**: The document was scanned for all potential dichotomous outcomes (e.g., number of patients needing rescue medication, number of patients with adverse events).

3.  **Efficacy Outcomes**: The main efficacy outcomes presented in the paper (Sum of Pain Intensity Differences (SPID), Peak Pain Intensity Difference (PID), Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR), time to remedication) are reported as adjusted mean scores (continuous data) in Tables 2 and 3 and the main text. These are not dichotomous (n/N) outcomes and therefore cannot be extracted according to the specified format. Although data on "pain at least half relieved (yes or no)" was collected, the results are only presented as a mean number of observations, not the number of patients achieving this at specific time points.

4.  **Rescue Analgesia**: The "Time to Remedication" is reported as a mean time (2.89 hours for the Codeine group). The number of patients who took rescue medication within the 6-hour study period is not provided, so a dichotomous rescue analgesia outcome (outcome_type 1 or 2) cannot be extracted.

5.  **Adverse Effects**: The sole source of extractable dichotomous data is Table 4, "Summary of Adverse Events by Number (%) of Patients". This table provides the number and percentage of patients experiencing specific adverse events for the Codeine 60mg arm (column C). The safety population (`n=39`) is used for this analysis.

6.  **Extraction of Adverse Effects**: In adherence to the "COMPLETE DATA CAPTURE" methodology, every adverse event listed in Table 4 for the Codeine 60mg group was extracted. This includes outcomes with zero events (e.g., Headache, Nausea/vomiting). The follow-up time for all adverse events is the 6-hour study period, as specified in the "STUDY EVALUATION" methods section. Each adverse event is recorded as a separate entry in the JSON output.

[[ ## reasoning ## ]]
The reasoning for the extraction is as follows:
1.  **Identify Intervention Group and Population Size**: The target intervention is "Codeine 60mg". According to Table 1, 39 patients were randomized to this group (`n=39`). This number is confirmed in Table 4 for the safety analysis. The efficacy analyses used n=37 for this group after two patients were excluded, as stated in the "Exclusions From Efficacy Analyses" section.

2.  **Scan for Dichotomous Outcomes**: The document was scanned for all potential dichotomous outcomes (e.g., number of patients needing rescue medication, number of patients with adverse events).

3.  **Efficacy Outcomes**: The main efficacy outcomes presented in the paper (Sum of Pain Intensity Differences (SPID), Peak Pain Intensity Difference (PID), Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR), time to remedication) are reported as adjusted mean scores (continuous data) in Tables 2 and 3 and the main text. These are not dichotomous (n/N) outcomes and therefore cannot be extracted according to the specified format. Although data on "pain at least half relieved (yes or no)" was collected, the results are only presented as a mean number of observations, not the number of patients achieving this at specific time points.

4.  **Rescue Analgesia**: The "Time to Remedication" is reported as a mean time (2.89 hours for the Codeine group). The number of patients who took rescue medication within the 6-hour study period is not provided, so a dichotomous rescue analgesia outcome (outcome_type 1 or 2) cannot be extracted.

5.  **Adverse Effects**: The sole source of extractable dichotomous data is Table 4, "Summary of Adverse Events by Number (%) of Patients". This table provides the number and percentage of patients experiencing specific adverse events for the Codeine 60mg arm (column C). The safety population (`n=39`) is used for this analysis.

6.  **Extraction of Adverse Effects**: In adherence to the "COMPLETE DATA CAPTURE" methodology, every adverse event listed in Table 4 for the Codeine 60mg group was extracted. This includes outcomes with zero events (e.g., Headache, Nausea/vomiting). The follow-up time for all adverse events is the 6-hour study period, as specified in the "STUDY EVALUATION" methods section. Each adverse event is recorded as a separate entry in the JSON output.

messages.content:
Your input fields are:
1. `markdown_content` (str): Full markdown content of the medical research paper including supplementary materials
2. `intervention_description` (str): Specific intervention to extract outcomes for (e.g., 'Ibuprofen 400mg', 'Placebo')
Your output fields are:
1. `reasoning` (str): 
2. `all_outcomes_json` (str): JSON string containing list of ALL outcomes for the specified intervention. Each outcome object must have:
        
        MANDATORY FIELDS FOR ALL OUTCOMES:
        - outcome_type (integer): Outcome type code where:
          1=Rescue analgesia at 6 hours
          2=Rescue analgesia at 4 hours  
          4=Rescue analgesia for pulpitis population
          5=Adverse effects (nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, dizziness, headache, etc.)
          6=Other outcomes (pain relief, time to onset, etc.)
        - follow_up_time (string): Exact time point when outcome was measured (e.g., "6 hours", "24hrs", "4 hours", "7 days")
        - n_analyzed (integer): Number of participants analyzed for this specific outcome
        - n_events_number (integer): Number of patients who experienced this outcome
        - n_events_percentage (float): Percentage of patients who experienced this outcome (e.g., 17.5, 0.6, 2.4, 0.0)
        
        CONDITIONAL FIELDS:
        - adverse_effect_specify (string): Specific adverse effect name if outcome_type=5 (e.g., "Drowsiness (sleepy, tired)", "Paraesthesia oral", "Vomiting"). Use "NA" if outcome_type5
        - other_outcome_specify (string): Detailed description if outcome_type=6 (e.g., "Time to meaningful pain relief", "Pain intensity difference"). Use "NA" if outcome_type6
        - adverse_effects_all_study (string): List of all adverse effects if not reported per study arm, or "NA" if reported per arm
        
        DOCUMENTATION FIELDS:
        - extraction_notes (string): Technical documentation including data source ("From Table 2", "From Figure 5", "From Supplementary Table 3"), extraction method ("Direct from table", "Interpreted from Kaplan-Meier curve"), and population used ("Per-protocol population", "Safety population", "ITT population")
        - comments (string): Study-specific information including single vs multiple dose design, surgical techniques mentioned, methodological features, dropout rates, calculation details
        
        EXTRACTION REQUIREMENTS:
        - Extract EVERY outcome reported, including zero-event outcomes (0/N)
        - Create separate entries for each time point assessment
        - Include outcomes from ALL data sources (main text, figures, supplements)
        - Use appropriate analysis populations (efficacy vs safety)
        - Document any calculations or interpretations performed
        
        Example: [
          {"outcome_type": 1, "follow_up_time": "6 hours", "n_analyzed": 40, "n_events_number": 15, "n_events_percentage": 37.5, "adverse_effect_specify": "NA", "other_outcome_specify": "NA", "adverse_effects_all_study": "NA", "extraction_notes": "From Table 3, per-protocol population", "comments": "single dose study with overnight monitoring"},
          {"outcome_type": 5, "follow_up_time": "24 hours", "n_analyzed": 40, "n_events_number": 7, "n_events_percentage": 17.5, "adverse_effect_specify": "Drowsiness (sleepy, tired)", "other_outcome_specify": "NA", "adverse_effects_all_study": "NA", "extraction_notes": "From safety table, safety population", "comments": "mild to moderate severity"}
        ]
All interactions will be structured in the following way, with the appropriate values filled in.

[[ ## markdown_content ## ]]
{markdown_content}

[[ ## intervention_description ## ]]
{intervention_description}

[[ ## reasoning ## ]]
{reasoning}

[[ ## all_outcomes_json ## ]]
{all_outcomes_json}

[[ ## completed ## ]]
In adhering to this structure, your objective is: 
        Extract ALL outcomes from medical research paper for systematic review.
        
        This implements COMPLETE DATA CAPTURE methodology - extract every data point
        including rescue analgesia, adverse events, and other outcomes at all time points.
        Focus on dichotomous outcomes from ALL data sources: main text, figures, tables,
        and supplementary materials. Include zero-event outcomes (0/N patients).

[[ ## markdown_content ## ]] # *Double-Blind Comparison of Meclofenama te Sodium Plus Codeine, Meclofenama te Sodium, Codeine, and Placebo for Relief of Pain Following Surgical Removal of Third Molars* # JAMES A. GIGLIO, DDS, MED,\* AND DANIEL M. LASKIN, DDS, MSt A single-dose, randomized, double-blind, parallel-treatment study was performed in 200 outpatients with acute pain caused by the surgical removal of impacted third molars. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, meclofenamate 100 mg, codeine 60 mg, and placebo treatment groups were compared for sum of pain intensity differences, peak pain intensity difference, sum of pain relief scores, peak pain relief, number of observations at which pain was half relieved, overall evaluation of effectiveness, and time to remedication with a backup analgesic. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg was significantly more effective (P < .005) than codeine 60 mg for all variables except number of observations at which pain was half relieved. Both meclofenamate-codeine combinations and meclofenamate 100 mg alone were significantly more effective (P < .005) than placebo for all variables. Eleven adverse experiences were reported in 7 patients (3.5%); the most common was somnolence in 1 patient receiving meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, in 2 treated with meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and in 1 treated with codeine 60 mg. Meclofenamate sodium (Meclomen, Parke-Davis Pharmaceutical Research Division, Warner-Lambert Co, Morris Plains, NJ), a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, inhibits prostaglandin synthesis and competes with formed prostaglandins for receptor sites. L-4 It has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for treatment of signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. Published literature provides evidence that meclofenamate is safe and effective in the treatment of patients with acute dental pain following third molar extraction,5q6 rheumatoid arthritis,'\*\* osteoarthritis,9-" ankylosing spondylitis,'2\*13 and gout,14 and for the pain of episiotomy.15\*'6 The objectives of this study were to assess the efficacy and safety of a fixed combination of meclofenamate, which acts peripherally, and codeine, which acts centrally, and to evaluate whether such a combination is more beneficial than either ingredient acting alone in patients with pain due to oral surgery. Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg was compared with its components, with placebo, and with meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg.17 Received from the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medical College of Virginia, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond. \* Associate Professor. t Professor and Chairman. Presented at the American Association for Dental Research, San Francisco, CA, March 1989. Address correspondence and reprint requests to Dr Laskin: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medical College of Virginia, PO Box 566, MCV Station, Richmond, VA 23298- 0566. **0 1990 American Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons** **0278-2391/90/4808-0003\$3.00/O** # Materials and Methods # **STUDY DESIGN** This was a single-dose, randomized, doubleblind, placebo-controlled, parallel-treatment study in outpatients with moderate or severe pain **caused** by the surgical removal of impacted third molars. Before the study, the protocol was approved by the Committee on the Conduct of Human Research of Virginia Commonwealth University. Each patient was supplied with a diary to record information on efficacy and safety over 6 hours following study drug administration and instructed to return it at the next scheduled visit to the study site. #### **PATIENT SELECTION** Selected for the study were outpatients at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery of the Medical College of Virginia, 16 to 37 years old, who were scheduled to undergo the surgical removal of impacted third molars, at least one of which was a partial or full bony impaction. Before participation, each patient signed a written informed consent statement, medical histories were taken, and physical examinations were performed. Patients were excluded from the study if they had medical conditions that contraindicated the use of any of the study medications or if they had known hypersensitivities, allergies, or idiosyncratic reactions to any of the study medications. Female patients were excluded if they were pregnant or nursing. In addition, no patient could be taking any medication that would confound the effects of the study drug or have taken any analgesics or anti-inflammatory agents within a 4-hour period before surgery. #### **ANESTHETIC REGIMEN** Patients were treated under local block (mandibular teeth) or infiltration (maxillary teeth) anesthesia using 2% lidocaine with epinephrine l:lOO,OOO supplemented with intravenous diazepam and N20/02 administered by nasal mask. If necessary, methohexital was given intravenously. # **STUDY MEDICATION** All study medications were identical in appearance. Each patient received a single dose consisting of one of the following: 1) one capsule of meclofenamate 100 mg and one of codeine 60 mg, 2) one capsule of meclofenamate 50 mg and one of codeine 30 mg, 3) one capsule of meclofenamate 100 mg and one of placebo, 4) one capsule of codeine 60 mg and one of placebo, or 5) two capsules of placebo. Backup medication of acetaminophen 300 mg plus codeine 30 mg, one or two every 6 hours, was provided to patients for use if additional relief from postsurgical pain was needed. # **STUDYEVALUATION** The efficacy evaluation was based on patient diary records. At 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 hours after taking the study drug, patients rated pain relief and pain intensity. Pain intensity was scored as none = 0, slight = 1, moderate = 2, or severe = 3. Pain relief was scored as none = 0, a little = 1, some = 2, a lot = 3, or complete = 4. Patients also indicated whether the pain was at least half relieved at each of the observation points (yes or no) and gave the time of administration of the backup medication. At the end of the 6-hour study period, each patient evaluated the study drug as excellent = I, very good = 2, good = 3, fair = 4, or poor = 5. A pain intensity difference (PID) score was calculated for each of the seven posttreatment observation times for each patient by subtracting the posttreatment pain intensity score from the one at baseline (a greater positive score indicates greater improvement). A sum of pain intensity differences (SPID) was then determined by adding the seven PID ratings; a sum of pain relief scores (TOTPAR) was determined in the analogous manner by adding a patient's seven pain relief scores. The variables of interest for efficacy were adjusted mean values for SPID and peak PID; TOT-PAR, peak pain relief, number of observations at which pain was half relieved; overall evaluation of study medication effectiveness; and time to remedication with a backup analgesic. The safety evaluation was based on the incidence and severity of adverse experiences that occurred during the 6-hour study period and were recorded in the patient diaries. # **STATISTICAL METHODOLOGY** As treatment groups were significantly different (x2 = 10.46, *P =* .033) with respect to baseline pain intensity, the statistical methodology for the effrcacy data used an ANCOVA with baseline pain intensity as covariate to adjust for this difference. (Although all patients had moderate or severe baseline pain intensity, there were significantly more patients with severe pain in the groups receiving meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg or meclofenamate 100 mg.) Pairwise f-test comparisons were performed on adjusted means. These adjusted mean scores are reported as least square means. Because there were 10 possible pairwise comparisons, a Bonferroni adjusted significance level of 0.005 (0.05 + 10) was used for every pairwise comparison to preserve the overall experiment-wide significance level of 0.05. Computation was performed using the SAS procedure General Linear Model. Summary tables were produced for adverse experience data. # Results # PATIENT POPULATION Two hundred patients, 35 men and 165 women, were enrolled and received study medication. There were 142 whites (71%), 51 blacks (25.5%), and 7 (3.5%) patients of other races, ranging in age from 16 to 37 years (mean, 22.7). Table 1 shows these data by treatment group, as well as the number of patients in each treatment group. There were no significant differences between study groups in mean time from end of surgery to treatment with study medication. #### EFFICACY ANALYSES # *Exclusions From Efficacy Analyses* There were no withdrawals among the 200 patients. However, 4 patients were excluded from all efficacy analyses. One patient who received meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg and 2 patients who received codeine were excluded because they took backup medication less than 1 hour after study medication. Another placebo-treated patient was excluded because she took the study medication intended for another patient 30 minutes after she took her own. One additional patient who received meclofenamate 50 mg and codeine 30 mg was excluded from the analyses for TOTPAR and # Table 1. Patient Characteristics peak pain value because she had two values for pain relief missing in the first 4 hours following study medication. # *Pain Intensity* Adjusted PID scores over 6 hours for each of the five treatment groups are shown in Fig 1. The group that took meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg had the largest mean values (greatest improvement) at each time point, followed by groups receiving meclofenamate 100 mg and meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg. Both codeine and placebo groups showed negative adjusted mean values during most of the study, indicating an increase in pain intensity from baseline: codeine from 2 to 6 hours and placebo from 0.5 to 6 hours. The statistical analysis of adjusted mean SPID and adjusted mean peak PID (n = 196) showed that meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg reduced pain intensity significantly more than either codeine or placebo *(P < 0.005)* overall and for peak values. In addition, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate 100 mg alone were both statistically superior to placebo for both measures (Table 2). # *Pain Relief* Adjusted mean pain relief scores over 6 hours are shown in Fig 2. Meclofenamate plus codeine produced the greatest pain relief over time. The poorest pain relief over time was observed for codeine and placebo: their adjusted mean scores ranged between 0 and 1 (0 = no relief, 1 = a little relief) for codeine at 0.5 and 2 through 6 hours, and for placebo throughout the entire observation period. The statistical analysis of adjusted mean TOT-PAR and adjusted mean pain relief demonstrated results analogous to those of adjusted mean SPID | Variable | Treatment (mg) | | | | | | |----------|----------------------|------------------------|-------------------|------------------|---------------|--------------------| | | M1OO+C60

In addition, pain was at least half relieved at significantly more observations with both meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate alone than with placebo alone. The mean results were meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 3.46 observations; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 2.59; meclofenamate 100 mg, 2.51; codeine, 1.52; and placebo, 0.74. # *Overall Evaluation of Study Drugs* Each patient evaluated the effectiveness of the study drug (the potential range was 1, excellent, to 5, poor; n = 196). Meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg had a significantly larger mean score (P < .005) than codeine or placebo. In addition, both meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg and meclofenamate 100 mg had a significantly better rating than placebo. The mean results were as follows: meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 2.15; meclofenamate IO0 mg, 1.87; meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, 1.65; codeine, 1.15; and placebo, 0.51. #### *Time to Remedication* Time to remedication was the time between taking the study medication and taking the backup medication. The meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and meclofenamate 100 mg treatment groups had significantly longer adjusted mean times to remedication with a backup analgesic drug (P < .005) than the placebo treatment group (n = 196). None was considered serious. Patients in the meclofenamate 100 mg and placebo treatment groups did not report any adverse experiences. The most common adverse experience was somnolence, which occurred in 1 (2.5%) of the patients who received meclofenamate 100 mg plus codeine 60 mg, 2 (5.0%) who received meclofenamate 50 mg plus codeine 30 mg, and 1 (2.6%) who received codeine 60 mg (Table 4). #### Discussion Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) have proven to be effective in relieving postoperative pain.18 Like all members of this class of drugs, meclofenamate acts peripherally by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis and by binding competitively at the prostaglandin receptor sites. Meclofenamate has also been found to be an in vitro inhibitor of human leukocyte 5-lipoxygenase activity. This study was undertaken to determine the feasibility and desirability of combining meclofenamate with codeine to obtain greater pain relief or control than can be achieved with either drug alone in conditions producing moderate or severe pain. Such a fixedcombination product may be clinically advantageous for patients requiring both central and peripheral analgesia. The results of this study show that meclofenamate with codeine provides greater pain relief. messages.content:
Your input fields are:
1. `study_metadata_json` (str): Study metadata as JSON string with first_author,  population_code
2. `intervention_json` (str): Single intervention details as JSON string with intervention_code, intervention_description, n_analyzed
3. `outcome_json` (str): Single outcome details as JSON string with all outcome fields including outcome_type, follow_up_time, n_events_number, etc.
Your output fields are:
1. `reasoning` (str): 
2. `structured_record_json` (str): Complete structured record as JSON string with exactly these fields:
        - First_Author (string): First author last name (e.g., "Cooper")
        - Population (integer): Population code (1-4)
        - Intervention_Code (integer): Intervention code (1-11)
        - Intervention_Description (string): Full intervention description with dose
        - Outcome_Type (integer): Outcome type (1=rescue analgesia 6h, 2=rescue analgesia 4h, 4=rescue analgesia pulpitis, 5=adverse effects, 6=other)
        - Outcome_Other_Specify (string): Detailed outcome description for type 6, or empty string for other types
        - Follow_Up_Time (string): Time point (e.g., "24hrs", "6 hours")
        - N_Analyzed (integer): Number of participants analyzed
        - Adverse_Effect_Specify (string): Specific adverse effect name for type 5, or empty string for other types
        - Adverse_Effects_All_Study (string): All study adverse effects if not reported per arm, or empty string
        - N_Events_Number (integer): Number of patients with this outcome
        - N_Events_Percentage (float): Percentage of patients with this outcome
        - Comments (string): Study-specific methodology, design notes, and extraction details
        
        FIELD MAPPING RULES:
        - For outcome_type 1,2,4 (rescue analgesia): Adverse_Effect_Specify="" and Outcome_Other_Specify=""
        - For outcome_type 5 (adverse effects): Outcome_Other_Specify="" and Adverse_Effect_Specify=specific adverse event name
        - For outcome_type 6 (other outcomes): Adverse_Effect_Specify="" and Outcome_Other_Specify=detailed outcome description
        - Always include extraction methodology and data source information in Comments
        - Ensure mathematical validation: (N_Events_Number/N_Analyzed)*100 = N_Events_Percentage
        - Use appropriate analysis populations (efficacy vs safety) based on outcome type
        
        Example: {"First_Author": "Cooper",  "Population": 2, "Intervention_Code": 10, "Intervention_Description": "Naproxen sodium 440mg", "Outcome_Type": 5, "Outcome_Other_Specify": "", "Follow_Up_Time": "24hrs", "N_Analyzed": 166, "Adverse_Effect_Specify": "Paraesthesia oral", "Adverse_Effects_All_Study": "", "N_Events_Number": 1, "N_Events_Percentage": 0.6, "Comments": "extracted from supplementary table 3, safety population, single dose study"}
All interactions will be structured in the following way, with the appropriate values filled in.

[[ ## study_metadata_json ## ]]
{study_metadata_json}

[[ ## intervention_json ## ]]
{intervention_json}

[[ ## outcome_json ## ]]
{outcome_json}

[[ ## reasoning ## ]]
{reasoning}

[[ ## structured_record_json ## ]]
{structured_record_json}

[[ ## completed ## ]]
In adhering to this structure, your objective is: 
        Structure extracted data into the final comprehensive dichotomous outcome format.
        
        This combines study metadata, intervention details, and any outcome data (rescue analgesia,
        adverse events, or other outcomes) into the standardized format used for systematic review
        and meta-analysis. Each record represents one outcome for one intervention in one study.

        - Intervention_Description (string): Full intervention description with dose
        - Outcome_Type (integer): Outcome type (1=rescue analgesia 6h, 2=rescue analgesia 4h, 4=rescue analgesia pulpitis, 5=adverse effects, 6=other)
        - Outcome_Other_Specify (string): Detailed outcome description for type 6, or empty string for other types
        - Follow_Up_Time (string): Time point (e.g., "24hrs", "6 hours")
        - N_Analyzed (integer): Number of participants analyzed
        - Adverse_Effect_Specify (string): Specific adverse effect name for type 5, or empty string for other types

        - N_Events_Number (integer): Number of patients with this outcome
        - N_Events_Percentage (float): Percentage of patients with this outcome
        - Comments (string): Study-specific methodology, design notes, and extraction details

        - Always include extraction methodology and data source information in Comments
        - Ensure mathematical validation: (N_Events_Number/N_Analyzed)*100 = N_Events_Percentage
        - Use appropriate analysis populations (efficacy vs safety) based on outcome type

        - Outcome_Type (integer): Outcome type (1=rescue analgesia 6h, 2=rescue analgesia 4h, 4=rescue analgesia pulpitis, 5=adverse effects, 6=other)

messages.content:
Your input fields are:
1. `study_metadata_json` (str): Study metadata as JSON string with first_author,  population_code
2. `intervention_json` (str): Single intervention details as JSON string with intervention_code, intervention_description, n_analyzed
3. `outcome_json` (str): Single outcome details as JSON string with all outcome fields including outcome_type, follow_up_time, n_events_number, etc.
Your output fields are:
1. `reasoning` (str): 
2. `structured_record_json` (str): Complete structured record as JSON string with exactly these fields:
        - First_Author (string): First author last name (e.g., "Cooper")
        - Population (integer): Population code (1-4)
        - Intervention_Code (integer): Intervention code (1-11)
        - Intervention_Description (string): Full intervention description with dose
        - Outcome_Type (integer): Outcome type (1=rescue analgesia 6h, 2=rescue analgesia 4h, 4=rescue analgesia pulpitis, 5=adverse effects, 6=other)
        - Outcome_Other_Specify (string): Detailed outcome description for type 6, or empty string for other types
        - Follow_Up_Time (string): Time point (e.g., "24hrs", "6 hours")
        - N_Analyzed (integer): Number of participants analyzed
        - Adverse_Effect_Specify (string): Specific adverse effect name for type 5, or empty string for other types
        - Adverse_Effects_All_Study (string): All study adverse effects if not reported per arm, or empty string
        - N_Events_Number (integer): Number of patients with this outcome
        - N_Events_Percentage (float): Percentage of patients with this outcome
        - Comments (string): Study-specific methodology, design notes, and extraction details
        
        FIELD MAPPING RULES:
        - For outcome_type 1,2,4 (rescue analgesia): Adverse_Effect_Specify="" and Outcome_Other_Specify=""
        - For outcome_type 5 (adverse effects): Outcome_Other_Specify="" and Adverse_Effect_Specify=specific adverse event name
        - For outcome_type 6 (other outcomes): Adverse_Effect_Specify="" and Outcome_Other_Specify=detailed outcome description
        - Always include extraction methodology and data source information in Comments
        - Ensure mathematical validation: (N_Events_Number/N_Analyzed)*100 = N_Events_Percentage
        - Use appropriate analysis populations (efficacy vs safety) based on outcome type
        
        Example: {"First_Author": "Cooper",  "Population": 2, "Intervention_Code": 10, "Intervention_Description": "Naproxen sodium 440mg", "Outcome_Type": 5, "Outcome_Other_Specify": "", "Follow_Up_Time": "24hrs", "N_Analyzed": 166, "Adverse_Effect_Specify": "Paraesthesia oral", "Adverse_Effects_All_Study": "", "N_Events_Number": 1, "N_Events_Percentage": 0.6, "Comments": "extracted from supplementary table 3, safety population, single dose study"}
All interactions will be structured in the following way, with the appropriate values filled in.

[[ ## study_metadata_json ## ]]
{study_metadata_json}

[[ ## intervention_json ## ]]
{intervention_json}

[[ ## outcome_json ## ]]
{outcome_json}

[[ ## reasoning ## ]]
{reasoning}

[[ ## structured_record_json ## ]]
{structured_record_json}

[[ ## completed ## ]]
In adhering to this structure, your objective is: 
        Structure extracted data into the final comprehensive dichotomous outcome format.
        
        This combines study metadata, intervention details, and any outcome data (rescue analgesia,
        adverse events, or other outcomes) into the standardized format used for systematic review
        and meta-analysis. Each record represents one outcome for one intervention in one study.
